newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Paccar takeover puts DAF on firm ground - analysts.
newsitem.headline: Paccar takeover puts DAF on firm ground - analysts.

text.p: Analysts on Friday hailed the takeover of DAF Trucks NV by Paccar of the U.S. as an all-important step in securing the future of the Dutch truck maker in a highly competitive European market.
"There is no chance of a DAF collapse now," said Jonathan Storey, director of U.K.-based European Automotive Research.
There had been a question mark hanging over DAF since it emerged in slimmed-down form from a 1993 bankruptcy, he said.
He said DAF's sales volumes were too small for it to survive as an independent company, but the friendly 933 million guilder ($544 million)takeover by Paccar now ruled out another collapse.

DAF Trucks made some 16,600 vehicles at its Eindhoven plant in 1995, and claims a nine percent share of the West European market for trucks heavier than 15 tonnes. As such it lags Mercedes-Benz DAIG F with an estimated 20 percent market share and Scania SCVa.ST with 15 percent.
"Paccar has chosen a good time to buy now DAF is more efficient," Storey said.
But Georges Dieng, auto analyst with Credit Lyonnais Securities in Paris, was less upbeat on the timing of the Paccar move.
"DAF is a good takeover target, but we are in a European (truck market) downturn," he said.
He said truck makers' orders were down 10 to 15 percent, and the situation was unlikely to improve over the next 12 to 18 months.
In the past, the trend had been for European manufacturers to seek a second market in the U.S. in a bid to create synergies in terms of components manufacturing, he said.

"Paccar is effectively doing the reverse...but I see no real synergy in terms of manufacturing a so-called world truck," he said. "Maybe they see it as a possible springboard to moving into markets further away...to getting a slice of the so-called new (eastern) Europe."
But Storey said the Paccar-DAF link-up offered significant scope for long term synergies in the areas of components, engines and axles, which represent a major percentage of a truck's total cost.

"Spreading the higher research and development spend resulting from tighter emissions regulations has been a driving force behind the collaboration between companies such as (Renault's truck division) RVI and (Germany's) MAN," he said.
He said new versions of existing DAF engines offered scope for collaboration with Paccar. "There is also scope to share cab componentry, which used to be quite difficult."

"I see the move as part of the long-term trend towards consolidation in the industry," he said, adding "now DAF is set to stay, the fierce competition on the European truck market looks like continuing unabated."
